history_of_present_illness: A 3-year-old boy presents with 2 days of cough and wheezing that worsens at night. Mother reports he has had similar episodes in the past triggered by upper respiratory infections. No fever. Taking albuterol inhaler with some improvement.
past_medical_history: History of recurrent wheezing episodes. No other significant medical history. Up to date on immunizations.
physical_examination: Alert and in mild respiratory distress. RR 32 temp 37.2C. Bilateral expiratory wheezing. Good air entry. No retractions. O2 sat 96% on room air.
treatment_plan: Viral-induced wheezing episode in child with asthma
learning_points: Inhaled bronchodilator every 4 hours. Start inhaled corticosteroid. Follow up in 48 hours. Return precautions given.
complexity_level: {"Viral infections are common asthma triggers","Early intervention prevents severe exacerbations","Patient education is crucial"}

history_of_present_illness: A 6-month-old previously healthy infant presents with fever to 39.5C for 12 hours. Poor feeding and increased fussiness. No cough runny nose vomiting or diarrhea. Parents concerned about serious infection.
past_medical_history: Previously healthy term infant. No prior hospitalizations. Fully immunized for age.
physical_examination: Ill-appearing infant. Temp 39.8C HR 160 RR 45. Fontanelle flat. No focal signs of infection. Capillary refill 2 seconds.
complications: Fever without source in young infant
topic_ids: Admit for observation. IV antibiotics (ceftriaxone) until blood culture negative at 48 hours. Supportive care.
evidence_level: {"Young infants have high risk of serious bacterial infection","Blood culture negative at 48 hours is reassuring","Close monitoring is essential"}

history_of_present_illness: A 12-year-old athlete complains of chest pain during basketball practice. Pain is sharp located over left chest and lasts a few minutes. No syncope shortness of breath or family history of sudden death.
past_medical_history: No significant medical history. Active in sports. No medications.
physical_examination: Well-appearing adolescent. Vital signs normal. Cardiac exam shows regular rate and rhythm. No murmur. Lungs clear.
learning_points: Reassurance. Activity restriction not needed. Follow up with primary care. Return for syncope or severe symptoms.
complexity_level: {"Most chest pain in children is benign","Red flags include syncope and family history","Thorough cardiac evaluation when indicated"}

history_of_present_illness: Parents of 2-year-old concerned about poor weight gain over past 6 months. Child eating well but not gaining weight appropriately. No vomiting diarrhea or other symptoms.
past_medical_history: Born full-term appropriate for gestational age. Normal newborn course. Developmental milestones normal.
physical_examination: Alert happy toddler. Weight 10kg (5th percentile) Height 84cm (25th percentile). Head circumference 48cm (50th percentile). Physical exam normal.
complications: Failure to thrive - likely inadequate caloric intake
topic_ids: Nutritionist referral. Increase caloric density of foods. Daily weights at home. Follow up in 2 weeks.
evidence_level: {"Most failure to thrive is due to inadequate intake","Growth charts are essential tools","Early intervention improves outcomes"}

history_of_present_illness: An 8-year-old previously healthy child had a generalized tonic-clonic seizure lasting 3 minutes at home. Post-ictal confusion for 10 minutes. Temperature 39.8C. No prior seizures.
past_medical_history: Healthy child. No medications. Family history negative for seizures or neurologic disorders.
physical_examination: Post-ictal child. Temp 39.9C. Neurologic exam normal once alert. No focal deficits. Kernig and Brudzinski signs negative.
topic_ids: Treat fever. Observe for recurrent seizures. Discharge home with seizure precautions. Neurology follow-up.
evidence_level: {"Complex febrile seizures need more evaluation","Most children do well long-term","Family education reduces anxiety"}

history_of_present_illness: A 15-year-old presents with 3 months of depressed mood social withdrawal decreased grades and sleep difficulties. Denies suicidal ideation but reports feeling hopeless.
past_medical_history: No significant medical history. No substance use. Family history of depression in mother.
physical_examination: Cooperative adolescent. Appears sad. PHQ-9 score 16 indicating moderate depression. No acute safety concerns.
complications: CBT referral. Consider antidepressant if no improvement in 6 weeks. Close follow-up. Safety planning with family.
topic_ids: {"Depression is common in adolescents","Therapy is first-line treatment","Family involvement is crucial"}
